moves.1. e4 c6 2. Nc3 d5 3. Nf3: The Two Knights variation of the Caro-Kann
moves.3... Bg4 4. h3 Bxf3 5. Qxf3 d4: This move takes White out of the book.
moves.6. Bc4 e6 7. Ne2 Nd7: Offering a pawn sacrifice in exchange for White's light-squared bishop
moves.8. Qg3 Nb6 9. Bb3 Nf6 10. d3 a5 11. a3: a4 would weaken the b4 square.
moves.11... a4 12. Ba2 Ra5 13. f4 Be7 14. O-O: This is a blunder. White can win with f5!
moves.15... Nh5 16. Qf3 g6 17. Rb1 Ng7 18. Bd2: Black makes another blunder, which allows Nxd4 followed by Bc3, skewering the knight on g7.
moves.20. Bb4 h4 21. Bxc5 Bxc5 22. Rbe1: Threatening to open the e-file with f5
moves.22... Nd7: Now White cannot push any of his pawns.
I felt that I was winning after this move.
moves.27. fxe5: White's best chance was b4 or b3.
moves.27... Nxe5 28. Qf6 Ne6 29. Rf1 Be7 30. Q: White exchanges an important defender for Black's worst piece.
Black sacrifices a pawn, but in return, he has trapped both White's King and Queen.
moves.38. Bxa4+ Kf8 39. Bc2 Kg7 40. Rf6f3: This is a mistake. Rb6 was best.
This blunder will end the game.
Here, White ran out of time.

gameName: Both White's King and Queen Get Trapped in the Corner Petrosian Style
